snippet: South Korea’s National Security Law was enacted in 1948 to fight Communism, but critics say it has been used as a weapon against political dissent and free speech.
abstract: South Korea’s National Security Law was enacted in 1948 to fight 'infiltration' of Communism from North Korea, but critics say it has been used as a weapon against political dissent and free speech; strictures of law have been particularly apparent following death of North Korean leader Kim Jong-il.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s National Security Law was enacted in 1948 to fight Communism, but critics say it has been used as a weapon against political dissent and free speech.

headline.seo: South Korean Law Casts Wide Net, Snaring Satirists in a Hunt for Spies
headline.main: South Korean Law Casts Wide Net, Snaring Satirists in a Hunt for Spies
headline.print_headline: South Korean Law Casts Wide Net, Snaring Satirists in a Hunt for Spies
